content.description: Easy face climbing leads up to a short overhang.  The crux involves reaching over a bulge to some good hand jams.  It felt like 5.10C to me (I'm 6'0"), but would likely be significantly harder if you're shorter than 5'11".  Above this overhang is a wild bombay chimney.
content.location: This climb follows the crack on the right end of the wall, just right of "It Don't Mean A Thing ..."

climbs.name: Red-headed Stranger
climbs.fa: Randy Vogel, Darryl Nakahira, and Dan Leichtfuss, 1980

content.description: Start to the right of the bolts; climb up and left to the first bolt.  Climb past three bolts and continue to the top.  This route is quite sustained, with tricky thin face moves.  It is well protected, and in shade most of the day.
content.protection: three bolts plus a few gear placements in horizontal cracks, and gear for the belay on top
content.location: This is near the left end of the face, with three obvious bolts.

climbs.name: It Don't Mean a Thing if it Ain't Got that Swing

content.description: This is the obvious center splitter through the overhang. Approach from the right via Solstice, or from the left via Ho Man. Either way, traverse in on a horizontal at the back of the overhang and then crank the bulge on fingers to rattly fingers. Rarely done, easy to access (not waaaay out there like many Wonderland routes).
content.protection: Thin to 2". For the roof itself, emphasize fingers and 1". No fixed anchor on top.
content.location: This is a really obvious splitter through the 5' overhang that looms above everyone walking into the southern Wonderland, on the left as you walk in, about 100' off the desert floor. Almost directly across from the Bankrupt Wall.
